comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Assuming these pictures were taken by Germans/Austrians/Hungarians, it seems as though an interest in ethnology was already in place. See also next photo: Collected works of M.A. Czaplicka, Volume 4 books.google.com/books?id=XyYm3TbTg1oC&pg=PA106&l... discusses different types of "turks" in the pre-WWI Russian empire -- largely from the perspective of religious affiliation. But it suggests the complexity of racial and tribal groupings in that part of the world. Aside: Turkey, as the name for the modern republic, was only established after WWI. According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Name_of_Turkey the name when used for a region was usually synonymous with Tartary in the Central Asian steppes. Between the 14th century and WWI, the Ottoman Empire covered those regions as well as modern Turkey and much of the Mediterranean and Middle East. Until the establishment of the Repblic of Turkey (1922) the words Turk and Turkish (or rather the equivalent in other languages) were used mainly as an ethnic designation and/or a class of language. More history at www.encyclopedia.com/topic/Tatars.aspx
